reviewText: I'm the first to admit that nostalgia can blind us to the true merits, or lack of, any number of artistic endeavors.  This is never more true than when viewing t.v. shows produced in the 70's and 80's.  I was nine years old when The Incredible Hulk premiered.  And, along with the Six Million Dollar Man, it was just about he coolest thing I'd ever seen.  Even then, I knew that the Hulk was just a big strong man in green makeup, But it didn't matter. . .it was a comic book come to life.  And what nine year old boy could resist that?It was, then with no small amount of trepidation that I approached my old favorite as a 39-year old man.  Would it seem cheesy now?  I hoped not, but somehow I figured it would have to.  Then I watched the pilot episode, probably for the first time at least 20 years.  And you know something?  There's not much childish about it.  I got hooked all over again on the grown-up problems of this man, David Banner.  I'm sure that in 1977, I endured all the drama because the payoff was coming: The Big Green Guy would come out and punish wrong-doers.  But I really gained a new adult insight into the show.  It's NOT about the Hulk, it's about David Banner.To be fair, none of the episodes in the series' short first season really quite live up to the feature-quality pilot.  But there's Bill Bixby, who makes Banner a wholly believable and sympathetic character.  Of course, there's plenty of action for the kid in us all.  And there's that tear-jerker piano theme that closes out each episode. . .as Banner must leave behind the new friends (or enemies) he's made and keep moving.  And for the cynical-minded, yes, there IS some cheesiness to be had (my favorite: as the Hulk wrestles a grizzly bear, green paint rubs off on the animal in several shots).In a world where nothing seems as good as it used to be (or maybe that's just middle age creeping up on me?), The Incredible Hulk still holds up quite well.

reviewText: Although I got the Ultimate Collection Disc set a couple of years back on Ebay I am glad they are now releasing the season 1 dvd.  I may hold off buying this disc set but check out the future seasons that come out.  In the case of the Ultimate Collection my favorites are: The First, Rainbow's End, Death In The Family, Mystery Man, 747 and The Harder They Fall.Like someone said in an earlier post it is a shame that older shows have to wait much longer to have DVD seasons released than tired, brand spanking new, not as interesting shows that have just finished up their first season and they are immediately rushed out to DVD!!  That happened in the cases of Lost, Grey's Anatomy and Desperate Housewives.Another thing that is odd.  It is a bit baffling as a fan for Universal to rush a 6 Disc set of multiple episodes then go back into season mode to put the episodes out in sequential order by season. But oh well- with a company like Universal it's all about the money!

reviewText: I never watched this show as a child, so these DVD's are my first exposure. And while I read comics, I never read "The Hulk". The character always seemed... cartoonish, silly. A boy's fantasy, and very obvious. This, though.... this is amazing. This is the boy's fantasy turned nightmare, the ruin of a life done with a light touch. I am deeply impressed with Bill Bixby's acting and with the cinematography, with the whole thing. I cringe at the transformation, but the special effects just weren't there back then so I can forgive that bit.I can't wait for the rest of the seasons to come out.
summary: Never watched it as a kid.

reviewText: First off, we finally have all of the original UNCUT episodes from season one of this awesome show.  Until I watched these, I never knew The Hulk smashed a gambling table in "Vegas."  Did the powers that be get a little lazy on the extras? Definately.  But then again, there is only so much on this show that was actually documented anyway.  Let's hope they release the whole series.What I loved about the first season was that the episodes (like the back of the box says) are truly heart pounding and suspenseful. Qualities (in my opinion) that the show lacked as the series progressed in later years.  Banner's transformations are sudden (which I LOVE). Later on, they gpt too predictable. Here's hoping for Season Two real soon. In my opinion, that was the best all around season of the show.

reviewText: Other than the Magician, The Courtship of Eddie's Father (Both which are unavailable on DVD yet) and My Favorite Martian, The late Bill Bixby's legacy will be playing Dr Banner on the Incredible Hulk. As Banner, he showcased the human side of a monster. Banner-A fugitive  from the law searching for a cure to his condition, make you see that man on the run, still had the milk of human kindness.Crated by Kenneth Johnston, who created such TV shows as V and Alien Nation, The Hulk took the Marvel comic to a new level. This Jekyll and Hyde story to a new height....and gave it a beating heartSomeone may  ask why this DVD set  only  4 stars....Well  the first season seem weaker story lines than in did in future seasons..but with Bixby and Johnston working together on these two pilot films and 10 episodes, these tv spisodes were good TVBennet Pomerantz AUDIOWORLD

reviewText: One of the most exciting television series of the late 70's and early 80's is now available on DVD thanks to Universal. The box set is awesome. The four disc set includes 10 episodes from season one, two made for television movies and a bonus episode "Stop The Presses" from season two.Universal really did a nice job with the box set, no dual discs here. Each colorful disc is enclosed in it's own slip case. Each plastic slip case includes it's very own Incredible Hulk related artwork.The set opens with the pilot The Incredible Hulk. In this episode, Dr. David Banner is still mourning the lost of his beloved Laura who died in a car accident one year prior. He desperatly tried to find the strength to lift the car in which she was pinned under be he couldn't and she died. Since her death, Dr. Banner has become almost obsessed with conducting experiments to find out how people find that inner reserve of super strength. In the process of doing an experiment on himself he accidently exposes himself to a high level of gamma radiation. Soon after he finds out that something very strange has happened to him. When he gets angry he becomes bigger, meaner, greener and turns into the Incredible Hulk!Although this show premiered nearly 30 years ago it holds up against the test of time. It's a very well written and successful show and the Hulk (Lou Ferigno) can still be a scary guy.As for special features their is episode commentary by writer, director and producer Kenneth Johnson on the pilot episode The Incredible Hulk.
summary: Excellent DVD Treatment For Incredible Hulk Season One

reviewText: ...the show didn't really get into a good storyline "groove" until the second season.  It did have some great moments though.I won't bore you with what everyone else has written, but I will tell you about something you may not know:  There were a number of scripts that were written for the 5th Season, but were never filmed, because CBS pulled the plug at the start of the 5th Season.  You can find (and even download) a number of these online by doing a simple Google search.The best of them is a script for an unfilmed episode entitled, "THE TRIAL OF JACK McGEE".  This would have been one of the best of the Banner-McGee confrontation episodes, if not THE best, and it's a real shame that it was never filmed.  I couldn't stop reading it once I started.  I spoke to exec. producer Kenneth Johnson about how the Banner-McGee conflict would finally end, and he states that it would have been resolved, probably by the end of the 5th Season, if the show had not been cancelled.  NO script had been written for the finale, however this "THE TRIAL OF JACK McGEE" script comes awfully close to bringing things to a head.  Search it out.  You'll enjoy it!The reason why the Banner-McGee thing wasn't resolved later on when the three NBC tele-movie reunions aired is because Bill Bixby took over as exec. producer, and Kenneth Johnson was no longer involved.  Too bad...

reviewText: For all the misgivings Universal has had in the past about releasing this amazing series properly, as a series, instead of as an "Ultimate Collection," it would have been cheaper to just release this series in seasons in the first place. A studio never really knows what they'll collect in profits until it's all said and done. Whatever their reasons, it about time!I've got to take my hands off to them, they encoded the first season in a high bitrate, which means it will look very good no matter the size of your screen. I always thought this series to be the best artistic interpretation of the Hulk comic books. The music is soulful and the show forces the viewer to feel for David Banner and his plight.The only thing that worries me is the bonus feature. It's an episode from the second season. Why would Universal do that. I'll tell you: They don't feel confident this box set will bring in the expected profits to justify releasing the second season. So, at least, in their corporate brains, you'll have an extra episode on the house. Ultimately, who the hell knows.But, buy in confidence. If you're going down memory lane, you won't be disappointed. This is one time you can visit the past and walk away from the experience just like you did when you watched it in the 70's.Enjoy!

reviewText: Back in the late 70's I was just a child already fixated on the power of episodic fantasy television. Even at this early age, shows like Star Trek, The Six Million Dollar Man, and Battlestar Galactica were mandatory viewing. But each of them paled in comparison to probably one of the finest comic book to television adaptations ever, The Incredible Hulk. Overseen by Kenneth Johnson of Six Million/Bionic Woman fame, this weekly show took some of the best aspects from the comic book, and added a few of it's own, to create one of the most well-written and acted shows of it's genre ever. Starring Bill Bixby as the forever-tormented David Banner and Lou Ferrigno as the beast of rage trapped inside him, this series about a doctor who searches for a cure to the gamma radiation he inflicted on himself to tap into his inner strengths, but turns him instead into a six and a half foot green monster whenever he gets angry, was so well done, both kids and their parents gathered around their TV sets to enjoy it week after week. Miles ahead in writing than most Sci-Fi series of it's day, this is one show that truly has stood the test of time.The Complete First Season pretty much sums up Hulk's first ever single-season release. You get all 12 episodes (two of which are two-hour ones being the Pilot and the first airing), plus a bonus episode from Season Two. While most fans have grown up with the reruns or seen them recently on the Sci-Fi Channel, the picture quality is much better here. Granted, print damage of specs and a few lines still exist, it's color spectrum and black levels are spot-on, making this viewing seem almost made recently. Audio hasn't changed with a decent 2.0 mono though. As for the shows themselves, Hulk started out with a bang, but does suffer a tad from "first season jitters". Basically following "The Fugitive" handbook, Hulk basicallykeeps the same pattern, with 2 "Hulk-Outs" per episode. But it's the acting that keeps you in. Not hokey or corny like other 70's shows, but with feeling and drama. Sure, the transformations today look terribly dated, but considering what they had to work with, it should be forgiven. The only other extra is a commentary that was previously released from a single disc version of the pilot, but with all 12 shows you won't feel cheated by a lack of them. A great look into a classic Sci-Fi/Action series humble beginnings.With all the recent Marvel films that have come out over the past ten years, this television chapter should be revisted by all. Minus the hairstyles and clothing, it truly doesn't look aged that much. And I would take an actual actor sprayed green over fakey cartoonish CGI anyday. A worthy addition to your Fantasy/Sci-Fi DVD collection.-RedSabbath Rating (8.5/10)-
summary: The Beginnings Of Comic Book To Television Greatness History

reviewText: Since the release of the final three films of The Incredible Hulk series, I (like many others) have wanted the original series to be released and someone finally heard us because here is Season One of one of the best adaptations of a comic book on either TV or the big screen ever! This 4 disc set was very riveting as the episodes are uncut and complete! Here is what you'll find:Disc 1Pilot - In the two hour premiere, we find Dr. David Banner still grieving for his failure to save his wife from an auto accident As a result, he is obsessed with finding the hidden strength that all humans have. When he discovers that gamma rays hold the key, he exposes himself to the mysterious radiation not knowing that he had it set too high! To his horror, he discovers that in times of stress and anger he transforms into a huge, raging and powerful creature which will become known as The Hulk!Death In The Family - In this two hour follow up, Dr. Banner runs across Julie. The daughter of a rich and powerful rancher who had died just recently. David takes a job at the ranch only to discover that Julie's caretakers are secretly trying to murder her to gain control of the fortune!Bonus Feature - Alternate commentary by Writer, Director and Producer Kenneth Johnson for "Pilot." This is actually on the solo release that came out back in 2003 as well.Disc 2The Final Round - In the first regular episode, Banner runs across a boxer who aids him in fending off some muggers. The boxer then helps Banner get a job at a local gym where the good doctor discovers that the gym owner is also a drug dealer and is looking kill his newfound friend!The Beast Within - A female scientist at a zoo is conducting experiements that may be a breakthrough for David's own condition but it runs a snag when certain other parties want to gain control of those findings as well.Of Guilt, Models & Murder - The Hulk has killed a woman......or so it seems!Terror In Times Square - While working in an arcade, Banner discovers a blackmailing scheme against the owner! This show features one of the iconic shots shown frequently throughout the series as The Hulk races down Times Square in New York!Disc 3747 - A robbery attempt on an airplane doesn't go as planned as David Banner and a young boy must land this 747 to avoid a major crash! One of the series' most legendary episodes!The Hulk Breaks Las Vegas - While working as a shill, David gets involved with a local reporter who's working to bust a gambling racket. This reporter, however, has ties to Jack McGee! The man determined to find and capture The Hulk and who also thinks that David is dead!Never Give A Trucker An Even Break - David aids a female trucker who's rig was stolen by smugglers. Not a great episode but watchable.Life & Death - While aiding a pregnant woman, David discovers a group called The Matrix who plans on taking her baby and using it for DNA experiments.Disc 4Earthquakes Happen - While trying to use a radiation unit to cure himself, David Banner is caught in an earthquake and now must use his own wits and the power of The Hulk to save himself and some workers at the research facility.The Waterfront Story - While in Texas, David Banner becomes involved with Josie who is an owner of a restaurant and is a widower herself. He also becomes involved in the ruthless world of union politics.Bonus FeatureStop The Presses - A taste of Season 2 as we find Banner trying to keep a picture of himself out of the paper for fear of being exposed while helping two female restaurant owners keep their business from going under thanks to a crooked reporter from The National Register.Overall, a very good ride! Worth the price of purchasing whether its here at Amazon.com or even at its regular price of nearly $[...]!
Title: N/A

reviewText: For fans who grew up watching this TV series, it really is a trip down memory lane. The acting and the stories are both fantastic. Even though this TV series got rid of the super villians from the comics, it shows that in this series, it is not needed. Thanks to the talents of Bill Bixby and Lou Ferrigno, this series is really a classic that will last for years to come.Bill Bixby is great as David Banner, the loner always searching for a cure. I really don't think this series would have had such a successful run for both adults and children if not for Bixby. He really makes Banner come alive and you have empathy for him in every single episode. Lou does a great job as well, he made the character of the Hulk real and you completely forget that it is really a guy in green paint. It does take some acting skills to make a man who in reality is  a man painted green not look silly but be taken seriously. Lou did a great job with it, thanks to the acting help he recieved from Bill.  I was never really a fan of Jack Colvin, but it can't be denied that he added to the story.There are many memorable scenes that still are amazing, even by today's standards, even though they make not look up-to-date. With the mixture of the great action Hulk sequences and the pain of David that everyone can relate to in one way or another, this series will live on with new fans watching for a long time!
summary: This Was And Still Is An Incredible Series

reviewText: Having grown up on this show through CBS and Syndication and being of the generation who were most likely exposed to the TV show before the comic book, I am ecstatic that they are finally giving the season by season treatment to The Incredible Hulk. I resisted the urge to buy the Ultimate Collection in the hopes that they would finally come to their senses and give this series the treatment it deserves. I didn't even know this was coming out, but was pleasantly surprised when I saw it at my local Borders and snatched it up right away. As a child I couldn't wait for the transformation each episode and watch Hulk wreak havoc, but as I've grown up I've come to appreciate the struggle of Dr. David Banner much more. The Incredible Hulk is probably my favorite TV show of all time, and it's about time they got around to releasing the entire series to DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Incredible Hulk" was my favorite show while I was growing up. Interestingly, I never got into the comic book; but the TV series intrigued me. I hadn't seen it in a long time, and I ordered it almost for old time sake and was afraid that I wouldn't like as much as I did while seeing the show through the eyes of a child or pre-teen.My fears were at once dsipelled upon my first viewing of the pilot episode (which I had never seen before). Bill Bixby, Lou Ferrigno and Jack Colvin were a great ensamble. Bixby has a warmth about him, and he generates a certain empathy, especially as he must go on at the end of every episode as a lonely fugitive. Ferrigno, of course, is outstanding as a body builder and captures the Hulk's spirit of intense anger juxtaposed by a childlike goodness. Colvin as McGee adds a tense edge and energy to each episode, even if his appearences are brief.The moving soundtrack also adds a certain pathos to this outstanding show.Through the eyes of an adult, I am still completely caught up in the Hulk myth.Despite high-tech CGI, the newer cinema version does not compare to the humanity behind the Bixby/Ferrigno/Colvin trinity.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In 1977 Kenneth Johnson who is a famous TV producer read the Incredible Hulk comics as he fell in love with them and wanted to make a TV show out of it for Universal Television. He consulted Stan Lee of Marvel Comics fame for the rights and they talked with the executives for CBS on this project as they decided to make it a more realistic show with no super powered villains like Leader, Rhino, Abomination etc. to make it in the tradition of The Fugitive TV series and down to Earth as if what if the Hulk existed in real life. They also had to change Bruce Banner's name to David as the executives thought the name Bruce sounded too flamboyant as they had to use it as his middle name as they changed it to David. It started with 2 TV pilot movies in late 1977 thus scored high ratings enough to be a TV show as intended as it lasted 5 seasons from 1977 till 1982. Bill Bixby was a very good choice to play David Bruce Banner and Lou Ferrigno who was a body builder plays the Hulk despite that Richard Kiel was intended for the role but Lou seemed very classy for the part. I gotta say this version of The Hulk is very memorable and beloved making tons of fans and does a nice Batman Begins-esque realism take on the Hulk mythology.We start off with the 1977 pilot TV movie "The Incredible Hulk" where it tells us the origin of the Hulk as it tells us the story of David Banner who had a good life with a wife until she died from a car accident yet Banner couldn't save her. One night after doing research on people's mysterious inner-strengths he decides to conduct a Gamma experiment but accidently overdoses on that alternating his body chemistry as whenever he is angry or outraged a transformation occurs turning him into a monstrous green-skinned ultrapowerful beast called The Hulk. His friend Dr. Ellen Marks (Susan Sullivan) is trying to help out with him find the cause of his hulking and where it comes from while investigative reporter Mr. Mcgree (Jack Colves) is hunting down the green goliath. But when an accident occurs at the labs place, Mcgee believes the Hulk was responsible for the death of Marks as Banner can't prove that neither him or Hulk didn't commit the murder as he decides to fake his death and leave town to other places to try to find a cure to be normal for he must make the world believe he is dead until he can find a way to control the raging spirit that dwells within him. "The Incredible Hulk: Death in The Family" deals with David drifting to a California town where he is still trying to find that cure of his condition as he runs into a lovely crippled girl and stays in for a while at her major house with a dysfuctional family as he finds out that her mother is trying a plot to kill her as Banner must reunite her with her estrange dad and try to report to the police as the reporter is still on the hunt for the green skinned beast.Disc 2 has "The Final Round" where David under a new name in Delaware where he must help out with a boxer named Henry Rocky Welsh as he discovers that Henry is delivering cocaine unknowingly as he must try to help him as he avoid a fight that could kill him in a fight with his high blood pressure. "The Beast Within" has David working at a city Zoo somewhere as he is helping on genetic research on animal aggression which maybe a key on trying to find something that could help him but discovers the zoo owner is smuggling diamonds within some animals in the zoo and must foil the plan. "Of Guilt, Models and Murders" deals with after Banner woke up in a city where he has transformed at the scene of a crime involving a model being killed, the Hulk is framed for the murder and David is hired to be an assitant to a model (Loni Anderson) as he also investigates who is behind the crime. "Terror in Times Square" has David under the name David Blake working at a New York City arcade and begins a friendship with the daughter of the owner but when the owner refuses to pay any protection fees, the mob boss takes him away.Disc 3 starts off with "747" has David taking a plane from San Francisco to Chicago in pursuit of a possible cure to his condition until a couple of crooks drug the pilots as David with a plane-smart boy must try to fly it to save the people on the flight. "The Hulk Breaks Vegas" is preciously what you believe in the title is about since Banner is in sin city as he takes a job in a casino and must help a reporter who's working on a report about a gambling scandal. "Never Give a Trucker an Even Break" has our hero trying to face off a band of hicks who stole a young woman's truck that belongs to her father, next up "Life and Death" has David in a small town as he volunteers for a DNA experiment and helps with a pregnant drifter woman who's about to have a baby as she plans to have it adopted as they discover a doctor is trying to do experiments on babies.Disc 4 begins with "Earthquakes Happen" where David is posing as another doctor in a city nuclear power plant on trying to gain access to a gamma experiment until an Earthquake occurs making a danger to the power plant until the Hulk must try to cool down the reactors, "The Waterfront Story" deals with David in Texas as he becomes a barkeep for a widowed boss until he knows about what happened to her husband as he must find out who wants to take control of a doc worker's union. We get a bonus episode from season 2 called "Stop the Presses" where Mcgee is in Chicago as well as Banner working in an Italian eatery as some reporter is trying to get the place shut down by planting gross stuff in the kitchen but can Banner get rid of the pictures of the evidence to prove the reporter did it or will the place be down in business forever?A must have for fans of the Hulk and TV shows
summary: An excellent TV Show now on DVD!

reviewText: I was so incredibly excited when I heard that my favorite tv series of all-time was coming to DVD.  I watched these episodes as a child and they are as good today as they were then.  This is a show that families can enjoy together.  David Banner's changes into his alter-ego, the incredible hulk, will appeal to the kids while the serious-themed storylines will connect with adults.  This is a quality show that needs to have all seasons released on DVD, so I would encourage all hulk fans to purchase this first season of some of the great early episodes that would set the tone for the entire series.

reviewText: The original dvd "release" was a collection of films that Universal thought we would like(and a un bi-passable and loud promotion of movie and Y2K series films no one in his right mind would be interested in!).  Finally all Hulk Seasons(well for now 1 and 2) are released(and likely will continue in 3-5) in complete episodes!  Season One to me was the best in that it was a tad more beleivealbe and less formulatic than #2-4(5 being a bit haphazzard).  Filming distributers get too involved with the artists who craft these(and other) series.  Season One had many things as D.B.(un-Hulked) doing a bit on the offensive trying to escape the mafia and the Lady Trucker antics that probably wouldn't go over in the rest. Also a formula of only two transforms per week was the constant predictiblity in later seasons and it was always at the first 15 minutes and the last minute of the show!(how lame!) I still enjoy all seasons(up to #3) and am glad of the releases of more than a handfull of the better ones(though not the best!). Where season two dealt with the PC themes and public issues better suited for Donnohue and Opra, Season One was for true fans of the series especially the Pilot(not counting "Death in the Famlily".)  The 747 was fun yet a bit cheezy and very franchies as the Hulk going into the passenger section not for story purpoes but to "RAAR!" at the seated  people.  Notoriously Incredible!  It happened quite a lot through out but didn't bother us 70's kids enough to swtich off the tan CRT in owr drably lit emergency yellow paneling planked family rooms...
summary: well, it's about time they realese these in Seasonal format!!!

reviewText: After being accidently exposed in his laboratory to a massive dosage of gamma radiation, David Banner (A Research Scientist) physiology was dramaticaly effected.Normally peaceful, quiet man, David now found that once angered, he turn into the Incredible Hulk, a huge, powerful seven foot greenish, manlike monster of immense strength and primitive passions.David knew and remember what happened at the start of his transformation but had no recollection of what he had done when he was the creature. He searched for a cure traveling around the country taking all sort of odd jobs in order to provide food and clothes for him self and in the same time avoiding the pursuit of investtigative reporter Jack McGee who suspected his secret but had no solid proof.The Incredible Hulk was based on the 1962 comic-book character created by Stan Lee.After two pilot movies in 1977, "The Incredible Hulk" a two parts first movie originally aired on November 4th,1977 and "A Death In The Family" two parts movie aired on November 27th,1977, the show was first telecasted on March 10th, 1978 until its last telecast on May 12th, 1982 for a total of 5 seasons and 83 episodes including the two pilot movies.The cast were:*David Bruce Banner ..... Bill Bixby*The Incredible Hulk ..... Lue Ferrigno*Jack McGee ..... Jack ColvinThe First Season consisted of 10 episodes not counting the two pilot movies and they are as follows:01- The Final Round - Aired March 10, 197802- The Beast Within - Aired March 17, 197803- Of Guilt, Models and Murder - Aired March 24, 197804- Terror in Times Square - Aired March 31, 197805- 747 - Aired April 7, 197806- The Hulk Breaks Las Vegas - Aired April 21, 197807- Never Give a Trucker an Even Breake - Aired April 28, 197808- Life and Death - Aired May 12, 197809- Earthquakes Happen - Aired May 19, 197810- The Waterfront Story - Aired May 31, 1978I wish all 5 seasons will be released soon after the First season.Thank you for reading my review, have a nice day :)
summary: Finally, The Incredible HULK is on DVD Season wise

reviewText: The majority of reviews I've read about this release concern many disgruntled fans complaining that universal have cocked it up again. I have to say I totally agree with them, for those who purchased the 'best of' set, its turned out to be a total waste of money, personally I did not buy this set.But Universal you do this all to often to loyal fans!Having said that though, I am grateful that its been released, its taken years and years for this to get a 'season' release and its good that its finally here. This is a great show and I have many memories watching this a kid on Saturday mornings. The stories and acting are superb.The only thing I will say though, is that our friends at Universal are well known for not releasing further seasons of a tv show if its first season's sales are poor, so I'd urge all fans to make sure they buy! I'm sure that pre-orders already warrent a second season release but you can never be sure.
summary: Fantastic show, one of the best!

reviewText: The parallels between this show and "The Fugitive" are obvious.  David Banner and Richard Kimble are both doctors.  Both shows revolve around the relationships that their characters form with people they meet on the road.  Both Banner and Kimble have respect/hate relationships with their pursuers; in Banner's case it's a tabloid reporter and in Kimble's case it's an obsessed detective.  The one major difference between the two shows is that Pete Rugolo's jazzy Fugitive theme has been replaced by something that sounds like "The Summer of 42" theme.  "Hulk" is an incredible time capsule of the late 1970's.  One episode has the hulk running through Times Square past numerous movie theatres showing movies of the period, such as "Coma" and "Saturday Night Fever".  An interior shot of an arcade in that same episode has pinball machines that I haven't seen for 25 years!  An episode set in Las Vegas has some nice shots of the downtown area in 1978 as well as mechanical slot machines of the time.  Martin Kove gives a great performance as a "Rocky" fighter hoping for a big break in an episode involving boxing.  An episode about truckers is an obvious parody of "Duel" complete with orange Dodge and rusted old big-rig truck. Another very relevant episode involves a nuclear research facility in Calif. when an earthquake hits--too bad the Hulk wasn't around to save everybody at Chernobyl. (This episode features an incredibly beautiful Sherry Jackson as the guest star).  The digital remastering on these DVD's is first-class and this is a really great-looking show the doesn't always look like it was filmed on the Universal back lot.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I grew up reading Spider-Man, Fantastic Four, Iron Man, The Incredible Hulk and many more Super Hero comics as a kid. When this show first aired, it was a difficult pill to swallow. The story was changed and the Hulk effects were somewhat laughable, but they did get a couple of things right! They cast a very likable Bill Bixby in the lead role as David Banner and the shows had heart! Why they changed Banner's first name from Bruce like in the comic book to David?.....well from what I've heard from Stan Lee is they thought Bruce sounded too..eh..G  A  Y!?  A ridiculous assumption, but TV exec's are a strange brood!The first season set consist of the first 2 pilot films and all 10 episodes from the first season. It would have been nice to have a few behind the scenes features, but it does have some commentary and bonus episodes which to me are a waste of space as Hulk fans are going to buy all the seasons anyway. The episodes look very clean and complete. I rate it 4 1/2 stars for a quality release.
summary: IF YOUR A FAN OF THE SERIES BUY IT!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The first season of The Incredible Hulk finally gets released, I skipped over the Ultimate Collection thankfully in the hopes for a season by season release.  For a long time I've been wanting to see the episodes, where I live they were never shown on T.V. but the pilot episode was available on tape.  After the horrible 2003 movie the desire to watch the good old Hulk was even more.These shows are mostly very good.  They're well written and well made but you can see they're pretty low budget, especially evident in two episodes where they "borrow" scenes from famous films and tie into the episode storyline.The cast is impeccable; Bill Bixby is not only a first rate actor but an extremely appealing guy who invokes complete sympathy for David Banner and the viewer never tires of him.  Jack Colvin is excellent as Jack McGee, the reporter who follows the Hulk every single time he's spotted somewhere.  And Lou Ferrigno...well he's the Hulk, pure and simple and will never be bettered.The show follows a simple formula down to a tee; David gets in trouble and the Hulk erupts and fixes things.  Sometimes David gets a little closer to possibly finding a cure but circumstances always prohibit him from succeeding.  Well, all fans know how this works.  And he always walks alone in the end.It's a formula, sure.  But they're well made, well written and some are very suspenseful and always keep viewers interested.Favourite episode; The Hulk breaks Las Vegas; a thrilling episode featuring McGee in a big role, terrific action and highly suspenseful.Least; Of guilt, models and murder; Despite a promising setup this episode is horribly acted by supporting actors, the writing is lame (only this one episode), substandard Hulk-outs and a silly conclusion.Overall this first season is very good with most episodes quite good.Here's hoping for a season 2 release soon.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In light of the much maligned genre of science fiction; this show was under rated for it's time.  Producer Ken Johnson didn't have a budget to put a sci fi slant on the show.  It proved to be one of the best dramas of the time.  I really have to credit the late Bill Bixby for pulling this off.  He really did a believable job of scientist Dr. David Banner.  I only wish that Lou Ferrigno got to speak a few lines as the Hulk.If someone were to update this concept it would have to be with an ongoing storyline.  The plots were a little one note but they still stand the test of time.  I have more of an appreciation now for the show that it's off the air.  Like Star Trek always attempted to show a moral with each episode; so did this show.  I noticed that the quality of the writing varys, but the show never failed to draw you in.With all the CGI in the Hulk feature film the producers of the movie failed in one area.  Showing the humanity of the Hulk as a character along with Dr. Banner's. This is where the TV show far surpasses the new movie...
summary: Finally the season sets have arrived

reviewText: This over-the-top Science-Fiction drama that made its series debut on Friday March 10th, 1978 was one of my favorite classic TV shows by Universal and this abbreviated season takes me all the way back to memory lane when I used to watch this show every Friday night on CBS after WONDER WOMAN, since WONDER WOMAN & THE INCREDIBLE HULK were part of CBS's Friday night line-up back in the Spring of 1978 when THE INCREDIBLE HULK made it's debut on CBS after completing 2 successful TV movie specials, which were the pilot episode and the "Death In The Family" episode, which were shown for the first time in November of 1977 along with the fact that this was the season when THE INCREDIBLE HULK was in its honeymoon phase of the show as well.As a matter of fact, those 2 movie special episodes were such a big hit that creator(Ken Johnson) and CBS had decided to make a TV series out of it, just like NBC did with BAYWATCH back in the Fall of 1989 after NBC had showed a TV movie called BAYWATCH:PANIC AT MALIBU PIER back in the Spring of 1989.The 1st Season also tells us how the ingenious scientist David Banner's affliction with the Hulk and Jack McGee's obsession with the Hulk(Lou Ferrigno) all got started since this was the season that explains to us that THE INCREDIBLE HULK was about a creature with remarkable strength that would turn up every time the reclusive David(Bill Bixby)got angry, injured, or extremely distressed that was accidently developed during an experiment on superhuman strength in the laboratory when widowed David becomes obsessed with not being able to rescue his wife from dying in a car accident and about a newspaper reporter(Jack McGee)who becomes obsessed with the Hulk after being assigned to follow up the story on the Hulk's first sighting.This season also explains to us how and why the Hulk was wanted for a murder he nor David could ever prove that the creature didn't commit and that Jack McGee(Jack Colvin) was the real culprit and the real person responsible for causing the death of David's fellow scientist Dr. Elaina Marks(Susan Sullivan), since McGee had accidently knocked over the acid in a storeroom that caused the lab to burn down and kill Elaina, which inclined David to fake his death and move around all over the country from coast to coast using different aliases while searching for a cure to his horrific ordeal with the Hulk while the obsessed McGee continues to track down the creature still convinced that the Hulk is a dangerous murderer to society, but amazingly throughout THE INCREDIBLE HULK's whole 4-year run on CBS; McGee never figured out that David Banner was still alive and that David was the guy who became the Hulk throughout the whole time McGee had pursued the Hulk.Something else I've noticed about this show throughout THE INCREDIBLE HULK's whole 4-year run on CBS is David Banner would always use a different alias with a last name beginning with a "B" working odd jobs all over the country to make ends meet while he continues to search for a cure to his intense affliction to the Hulk and sometimes David even ended up using the same alias more than once like David Bernard, David Brown, David Barnes, David Burns, David Blake, David Benton, David Barrett, David Barton, etc., but I'm just surprised that David never used David Berkeley or David Burke for an alias since the last names Berkeley and Burke are quite common last names with a B in it.It was also interesting seeing*Gerald McRaney in the "Death In The Family" episode before his co-starring days as the short-tempered gonzo private investigator(Rick Simon)on SIMON & SIMON, and before his co-starring days on MAJOR DAD, and TOUCHED BY AN ANGEL*Lonnie Anderson in the "Of Guilt, Models, & Murder" episode during her co-starring days on WKRP IN CINCINATTI and before her days of being a superstar*Susan Sullivan in the pilot episode before her co-starring days on FALCON CREST & before her days of being the spokesperson for the TYLENOL commercials in the mid 1980's.*Martin Kove in "The Final Round" episode before his co-starring days on the police drama CAGNEY & LACEY and THE KARATE KID*Mills Watson in the "Death in the Family" episode before his co-starring days as the doofus Deputy Perkins on SHERIFF LOBO*Charles Siebert in the pilot episode during his co-starring days on TRAPPER JOHN M.D.*James Sikking in "The Waterfront Story" episode before his co-starring days as Lt. Howard Hunter on the police drama HILL STREET BLUES*William Daniels in the "Death In The Family" episode before his co-starring days as Mr. Feeny on BOY MEETS WORLD and before his co-starring days as the salty high-strung Dr. Mark Craig on ST. ELSEWHERE and before Daniels days of being the voice of KITT on KNIGHT RIDER*Caroline McWilliams in "The Beast Within" episode after her co-starring days on GUIDING LIGHT*Kene Holliday in the "Earthquakes Happen" episode before his co-starring days on MATLOCK*Jennifer Darling in the "Never Give A Trucker An Even Break" episode after her co-starring days on THE BIONIC WOMAN and THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN*Andrew Robinson during his co-starring days on RYAN'S HOPEI also learned some interesting facts about this show that I never knew before like how creator(Ken Johnson)changed the name of the Hulk's comic book alter ego from Dr. Robert Bruce Banner to Dr. David Banner for the TV series on CBS, due to not wanting the series to be perceived as a comic book series, so Johnson wanted to change what he felt was a staple of comic books and comic book creator(Stan Lee)comics in particular that major characters frequently had alternative names.Johnson also added on the commentary of the pilot episode of this show that the revisions of the characters names was a way of honoring his late son(David Johnson).In addition to why Universal changed the character name of Dr. Bruce Banner to Dr. David Banner was because the name "Bruce Banner" sounded in the eyes of the network like a gay character name and "David Banner" sounded much better, according to Stan Lee.On an interview with Johnson, Johnson explains to us that he wanted the Hulk to be colored red instead of green, because red, not green is perceived as the color of rage along with the fact that red is a human color, unlike green, but Stan Lee insisted for the Hulk to remain green, which Johnson eventually consented to.Johnson also explains to us that cast veteran actor/director(Bill Bixby)was Johnsons first choice to play the role of Dr. David Banner, but that Bixby had resisted accepting the part, but then after Bixby read the script he quickly signed on after actor(Larry Hagman)from DALLAS and I DREAM OF JEANNIE had turned down the role to play Dr. David Banner.In addition, the most daunting task was finding someone compatible to play the Hulk.  Actor/now California Governor(Arnold Schwartzenegger) auditioned for the part, but was rejected due to his inadequeate height, according to Ken Johnson.In addition to that, actor(Richard Kiel)who played Jaws in some of the James Bond movies with Roger Moore including MOONRAKER, was hired to play the Hulk and production commenced on the pilot movie and during filming, Johnson's own son pointed out that Kiel was tall, but his underdeveloped physique didn't resemble the Hulk at all.Therefore Kiel had the height, but didn't have the build, so Kiel was replaced by Schwartzeneggers former body-builder rival(Lou Ferrigno)although a very brief shot of Kiel as the Hulk remained in the pilot movie, according to Johnson.Johnson also added that his reason for giving Lou Ferrigno to play the Hulk was also due to the fact that Richard Kiel who sees properly out of only one eye reacted badly to the white contact lenses used for the role of the Hulk, plus Kiel found the green make-up used to play the role of the Hulk very difficult to remove, so Kiel didn't mind losing the part of playing the Hulk when it was given to Ferrigno along with the fact that this was Ferrigno's very first acting gig since Ferrigno had no acting experience at the time.Its just too bad that THE INCREDIBLE HULK couldn't last longer, despite its popularity and astonishing ratings since CBS had decided to cancel this show all of the sudden in the middle of its 5th Season run in November of 1981 after only 7 weeks after only showing the first 5 episodes of THE INCREDIBLE HULK's 1981-82 Season since this show was cancelled due to budget cuts & a change in management at CBS in the Summer of 1981 along with the fact that the special effects got too expensive to keep running this show, because of the recession we had back in 1981-1982 when Ronald Reagan was the president, which is why I partly blame Reagan for this show being axed on such short notice.Therefore since the special-effects for the Hulk-Out scenes were getting too expensive from the budget cuts, Ken Johnson would have had to make some major cutbacks on the special effects by having David only do one Hulk-Out per episode instead of 2 Hulk-Outs per episode and/or would've had to make the special effects and feats of strength a lot less impressive, which would've made the ratings sink immensely along with the fact that THE INCREDIBLE HULK had the most expensive special effects on TV at the time, which were even more expensive than BATTLESTAR GALACTICA's.Therefore, in order to help save the show from being cancelled from low ratings, Ken Johnson had to make some compromises with CBS after CBS had unofficially announced in July of 1981 that THE INCREDIBLE HULK was going to be axed even though the Hulks 5th Season was already in the works with 7 episodes in the can, which resulted in CBS only making THE INCREDIBLE HULK's Fifth Season half a season with only 7 remaining episodes of this science-fiction drama instead of cancelling the show by September of 1981 after its Fourth Season run, but nobody else really knew that THE INCREDIBLE HULK was going to be cancelled that year because of hefty budget restraints and a change in management at CBS, especially when CBS just took it off the air without sufficient warning in the mid Fall of 1981, but CBS had decided to bring the show back on the air temporarily in the Spring of 1982 to finish off its last 2 remaining 5th Season episodes back in May of 1982.Unfortunately, CBS never made a series finale episode of this show leaving us wondering if David Banner ever really ended up finding a cure to his struggling ordeal with the Hulk since the last episode "A Minor Problem " indicated to us at the end of that episode that David was still searching for a cure which obviously led us to the conclusion that David & McGee still had some unfinished business with the Hulk.In addition to what led to THE INCREDIBLE HULKs sudden cancellation in mid November of 1981; THE INCREDIBLE HULK had a slight decrease in ratings and the president of CBS at the time(Harvey Shepherd) felt that the Hulk was running out of steam, which Johnson and I strongly disagree on, but another thing that resulted in this 1981-1982 Season being an abbreviated season was rumor had it that Bix's contract was up and that Bix wanted to move on and have his Banner character finally be cured from the Hulk, according to Ken Johnson.Therefore, THE INCREDIBLE HULKs sudden cancellation in the mid Fall of 1981 was very similar to when CBS had cancelled WONDER WOMAN all of the sudden back in the early Fall of 1979 since CBS led us to believe that WONDER WOMAN was going for a 4th Season after showing the last 2 episodes of WONDER WOMAN, which were "The Man Who Could Not Die" & "The Phantom Of The Rollercoaster" episodes on their original air-dates just before WONDER WOMAN was axed on CBS on such short notice in mid September of 1979.Therefore, it turned out that "The Man Who Couldn't Die" episode & "The Phantom Of The Rollercoaster" episode were only the remaining last 2 episodes of WONDER WOMANs 3rd Season as well as the last 2 episodes throughout WONDER WOMANs whole 3-year run and chances are CBS already had plans underway back in the Summer of 1979 to cancel WONDER WOMAN in the Fall of 1979 just like CBS already had plans to ax THE INCREDIBLE HULK in the Summer of 1981 when they had uncerimoniously announced that THE INCREDIBLE HULK was being cancelled in the Fall of 1981.Original air-dates to each of the Hulk's 1st Seasons episode are11/4/77: PILOT EPISODE11/27/77: DEATH IN THE FAMILY3/10/78: FINAL ROUND3/17/78: THE BEAST WITHIN3/24/78: OF GUILT, MODELS, & MURDER3/31/78: TERROR IN TIMES SQUARE4/7/78: 7474/21/78: THE HULK BREAKS LAS VEGAS4/28/78: NEVER GIVE A TRUCKER AN EVEN BREAK5/12/78: LIFE & DEATH5/19/78: EARTHQUAKES HAPPEN5/31/78: THE WATERFRONT STORY
summary: Don't Make Me Angry...You Wouldn't Like Me When I'm Angry!
